name: Northern Talapoin
description: Talapoins are the smallest African primates. They have a slender body, long limbs and tail (not prehensile), and a small, round head. Their fur is olive-green to gray-green on top, with a yellowish tinge on the sides and limbs. The face is pink, and the underbelly is whitish.
spread_note: Western tropical Africa north of the Zaire River
food_note: Various plant parts (fruits, leaves, flowers, shoots), smaller animals
image_alt: Northern Talapoin, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
attractions: Talapoins live in large, loose groups (sometimes over 100 individuals), splitting into subgroups during the day and gathering in tree canopies near water at night. They are fond of flooded areas, swim well, and even dive for food—unique among monkeys.
breeding: Talapoins inhabited the old Monkey Pavilion from 1960 until its demolition in 1999. A new breeding phase began in 2006 with three pairs from the wild; the first successful breeding occurred in 2008.
